item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

why are you creating a new instance? you want to get the existing instance wherever it is stored

item.title: Beginner's Question: Hooking the Canvas
item.dc:creator: @Wewt Wewt
item.description:
@Wewt wrote:

Thanks everyone, I got it working

Edit: Okay, maybe not. I’ve got it so that I can write on the client, but now, I’m trying to access the class’s inherited getCanvas method, which I’m doing by try { Class clz = Class.forName("uj"); Object obj = clz.newInstance(); Method[] methods = clz.getMethods(); Method toDo = null; for(Method m : methods) { if(m.getName().equals("getGraphics")) { toDo = m; toDo.setAccessible(true); } } if(toDo != null) { Graphics g = (Graphics) toDo.invoke(obj, null); } } catch(Exception e) { e.printStackTrace(); }
I’m getting an InstantiationException however. Anyone know how to fix this?
Sorry for the stream of questions

Read full topic

c = (Component) f.get(null);
evidently it’s an instance field

@the_bank wrote:

Of course you can’t change the super class with reflection, and even if it was possible it wouldn’t be permanent.

Why do you need a canvas hook? If you want painting, then you don’t need one; take a look here and here instead.

item.title: Beginner's Question: Hooking the Canvas
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

InstantiationException - if this Class represents an abstract class, an interface, an array class, a primitive type, or void; or if the class has no nullary constructor; or if the instantiation fails for some other reason.

Read full topic

item.title: Beginner's Question: Hooking the Canvas
item.dc:creator: @Wewt Wewt
item.description:
@Wewt wrote:

Hi there.
I recently got into Runescape client hacking from reading some tutorials on another site.
Right now, I’m trying to figure out how to hook RuneScape’s canvas.

I found that the Canvas class is “uj” in the current build, so first I tried this:

[code] public void getCanvas() {
try {
Class clz = Class.forName(“uj”);
c = (Canvas) clz.newInstance();
} catch(Exception e) {
e.printStackTrace();
}

}[/code]

I thought this would work, because the class uj extends the Canvas, but I get a InstantiationException.

So then I tried using the field “a”, because it is a Component, so I did this:

[code] public void getCanvas() {
try {
Class clz = Class.forName(“uj”);
Field f = clz.getDeclaredField(“a”);
f.setAccessible(true);
c = (Component) f.get(null);

    } catch(Exception e) {
        e.printStackTrace();
    }


}[/code]

And I get a NullPointerException.
What am I doing wrong? Just a hint would be nice. Am I even looking at the right class?

Sorry if this is a newbie question, and thanks.

Read full topic
